comment._content: As a Major (commanding 6 Gurkha at the time) he led his battalion and a detachment of 6th South Lancs in the capture of Hill Q, on the Sari Bair heights at Gallipoli in August 1915. Only briefly held, his small party without any reinforcements were shelled and then charged off the heights by the Turkish defenders. He was originally put up for the VC, but received the DSO instead ... Stephen C

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Promoted to Colonel after the War, Cecil John Lyons Allanson was awarded the CMG and CIE in addition to his DSO.  Allanson was serving on the General Staff in 1918 - he is quoted in David R. Woodward's work 'Lloyd George and the Generals' pp 231-232.  He was Commanding Officer of 2nd/6th Gurkha Rifles from 1922-27.

A book has been published of his military career:  "Allanson Of The 6th. An Account Of The Life Of Colonel Cecil John Lyons Allanson CMG, CIE, DSO, 6th Gurkha Rifles, Compiled From Letters And Personal Papers."//

comment._content: An oil on canvas was painted by Terence Cuneo (1907-96) in 1981. Title: Sari Bair - 1st Battalion 6th Gurkha Rifles led by Major C. J. L Allanson attacking the Turks on the crest of Sari Bair ridge, Gallipoli, 9th August 1916. Location: Gurkha Museum, Winchester, England www.bridgemanart.com/asset/194959/Cuneo-Terence-1907-96/S...
